title: How to Make Minnesota Wild Rice Chicken Soup

text: Boil 6 cups of water in a large saucepan. Add 2 teaspoons of salt and 3/4 cup of raw wild rice. Cook for one hour, stirring occasionally. Drain in a colander; then set aside while preparing the rest of the soup. In a large stock pot, heat 1/2 cup of butter over medium heat. Once the butter is melted, add the chopped celery, carrots, and onion. Stir to coat the vegetables evenly with the butter. Simmer the vegetables in the butter for about 8 minutes, or until they begin to soften. Next, sprinkle in 1/3 cup flour, stirring constantly. Heat the flour/butter mixture for 2 minutes to create a roux. Stir in the cubed chicken pieces and cook the chicken until no pink remains in the interior.  Pour 5 cups chicken broth into the pot and stir to incorporate the broth and roux. Simmer for about 5 minutes, stirring often. Next, turn the heat down to low and slowly add 2 cups of half-and-half, stirring constantly. Add the cooked wild rice, rosemary, dill, fennel seeds, and nutmeg. Simmer the soup for 1 1/2 to 2 hours on low heat, stirring occasionally. It is important not to let the soup boil rapidly, because boiling can cause the soup to scorch the bottom of the pot and force the cream broth to break. Once the soup is finished, season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve the soup with crackers or bread to create a complete, hearty meal. Finished.
